en.title: GNOMATIC STRATA ANALYZER
en.restartDesc: Press CONFIRM to restart the level.
en.dialogCollectionLocked: You must continue to play the game to access this knowledge.
en.credits_desc:
Written By: David Dionisio
Music From: Kevin Macleod
en.introDialog1: This is the Gnomatic Strata Analyzer, the latest in technology for studying the History of Planet Earth.
en.introDialog2: Why don't you take it for a spin and uncover the deep mysteries of Earth!
en.introStratigraphyDetail1: A layer of rock is called a stratum. The study of these layers is called Stratigraphy. Each layer has a unique story to tell about the Earth.
en.introStratigraphyDetail2: Each layer of rocks can give us information about the Earth's past.  These are categorized in geological time scale.
en.introLawStratigraphySuperpositionDesc: Younger layers of rock sit atop older rocks.
en.introLawStratigraphyOriginalHorizontalit: Sediments were deposited in flat layers. A tilted layer indicates a disturbance driven by external force such as earthquakes.
en.introLawStratigraphyCrossCuttingDesc: A layer of rock can fill between the gaps of broken up layers. This layer of rock is considered to be an intrusion and is the youngest among the layers.
en.introLawStratigraphyLateralContinuityDes: Layers of rock fill up horizontally until it is broken apart by powerful forces such as water and earthquake. Layers on both sides will match up.
en.rock_sedimentary_sandstone_desc: Sandstone is a sedimentary rock composed of broken up rocks and minerals. Its texture is rough and course with a wide range of colors.
en.rock_metamorphic_marble_desc: Marble is a metamorphic rock with cloudy patterns. It is formed from minerals that have crystalized due to pressure and heat. This makes the rock very hard and sturdy.
en.rock_igneous_gabbro_desc: Gabbro is a coarse-grained igneous rock. Its color is usually black or dark green. Gabbro is commonly found in the deep oceanic crust.
en.rock_metamorphic_gneiss_desc: Gneiss is a metamorphic rock with stripe patterns. Its stripes are formed from pre-existing rock formations that have undergone transformation due to high pressure and heat.
en.rock_ingeous_granite_desc: Granite is a light-colored igneous rock with large visible grains. It's mostly composed of quartz and feldspar, making it hard and tough. Granite's color is mostly white, pink, or gray.
en.rock_metamorphic_quartzite_desc: Quartzite is a metamorphic rock made from quartz. These quartz come from sandstone that has morphed due high pressure and heat.
en.fossil_perisphinctes_desc: Perisphinctes is a type of mollusk that lived during the Jurassic Period. They are considered to live in tropical shallow waters worldwide.
en.fossil_dimetrodon_desc: Dimetrodon is a mammal-like reptile that lived during the Permian Period. Their spines are stretched to form a shape like that of a sail. Dimetrodons are the apex predators of its time, preying upon aquatic animals.
en.fossil_opabinia_desc: Opabinia is an arthropod much like shrimps that lived during the Cambrian Period. Their body is soft with five eyes, gills on the sides, and a fan-shaped tail. Their mouth extends from beneath their head.
en.fossil_glossopteris_desc: The Glossopteris is a type of fern that arose during the beginning of the Permian Period. The name is based on the appearance of its leaves that are shaped like a tongue.
en.fossil_triceratops_desc: Triceratops is a genus of herbivorous ceratopsid dinosaur that lived during the Cretaceous Period. Their unique features are the three horns on their face, and the large bony frill. The Triceratops were herbivorous. Based on their size and teeth structure, they must have eaten fibrous and woody plants.
en.fossil_ankylosaurus_desc: Ankylosaurus is a genus of armored dinosaur that lived during the Cretaceous Period. Their body is covered in armor plates, and their tail is shaped like a club. The Ankylosaurus is an herbivore. Based on the position of their head, they most likely stuck to eating ferns and shrubs (lots of it).
en.fossil_mastodon_desc: Mastodons are a species of proboscideans in the genus Mammut, distantly related to elephants. They lived during the Neogene Period. The Mastodons were predominantly forest dwelling animals that fed on various diet obtained from trees and such, much like elephants.
en.fossil_smilodon_desc: Smilodon, also known as the sabre-tooth cat, is a genus of machairodont felid. They lived during the Neogene Period. The Smilodons were an apex predator, hunting down large mammals such as bisons. Based on fossil findings, they most likely lived in a closed habitat such as forest.
en.fossil_paradoxides_desc: Paradoxides is a genus of large trilobites (marine arachnomorph arthropods) that lived throughout the world during the Cambrian Period.
en.fossil_stegosaurus_desc: Stegosaurus is a genus of thyreophoran dinosaur that lived during the Jurassic Period. They were a large, heavy quadrupeds with plates growing out of their rounded back. Their tail also had spikes growing out of it, most likely used for defense against predators.
en.result_1_question: Which rock layer is the oldest:
en.result_1_question_2: Which rock layer is the youngest:
en.result_1_end: By looking at how the Gabbro layer goes across the other layers, we can determine it to be the youngest based on Cross-cutting Relationships.
en.result_2_question: Which one of these is an Index Fossil?
en.result_2_end: Index Fossils are used to determine the Geological Timescale of a layer. It can also allow us to correlate layers from one area to another, as far apart as distant continents.
en.indexFossilCriteriaDesc:
- The fossil must be easily recognizable and distinct.
- It must be found over a large area.
- It must have lived for a short time, such that it's only found in one stratum.
en.result_2b_question: Which layer does this correlate to in Column B?
en.result_2b_end: Index Fossils allow us to correlate rock layers from one area to another. These layers can be as far apart as distant continents.
en.result_3_question_1: What would be the climate at the bottom of the boundary?
en.result_3_question_2: What would be the climate at the top of the boundary?
en.result_3_end: The K-Pg Boundary (or K-T) is a key bed where its minerals come from a meteor. Based on the evidence of fossils found between the border, it is suggested that a mass extinction has occured due to a rapid change of climate.
en.result_summary_rockCycle: Rocks are continuously changing forms across time as they are lifted up above the Earth and sank back down below.
en.rockSedimentDesc: Sedimentary rocks form when sediments cement together after a long period of time. These sediments come from various sources through weathering and erosion.
en.rockIgneousDesc: Igneous rocks form when magma cools off and solidify into crystals.
en.rockMetamorphicDesc: Metamorphic rocks form when pressure is applied to other rocks. The heat from pressure causes the rock to further harden and change form.
en.result_question_superPosition: Determine the youngest and oldest rock layer:
en.result_summary_superPosition: Based on Superposition in the Laws of Stratigraphy: Younger layers of rock sit atop older rocks.
en.tutorialDialog: Press anywhere to launch the Gnomatic!
